awd_titl_txt: EAGER:  UVC microbial inactivation within model water treatment membrane modules via X-ray-driven radioluminescence
awd_abstract_narration:
1551534
Cates

Membrane processes are now being used for many environmental applications such as drinking water and wastewater treatment. They are also used in indirect potable reuse and desalination plants. One of the single biggest issues is membrane fouling which increases the operational and maintenance cost. This project uses ultraviolet radioluminescence, a potentially transformative tool for membrane biofouling prevention, with many theoretical advantages over chemical antimicrobial strategies currently being researched. 

The concept, conceived by the PI, involves incorporation of inorganic phosphor materials within reverse osmosis or nanofiltration membrane module feed channels, which emit germicidal ultraviolet radiation when excited by X-rays. The penetrating ability of high-energy X-rays could thus allow controllable ultraviolet treatment within the typically inaccessible confines of spiral-wound modules by employing externally-situated X-ray sources to excite the phosphors within. This approach is attractive in theory, but its predicted feasibility currently relies on cursory simulations involving simplified scenarios and approximate values of X-ray attenuation, phosphor efficiency, and microbial UVC dose response from the literature. In order to predict if RL membrane biofouling control (RMBC) can become a viable technology in the future, the PI proposes to conduct exploratory research involving simplified proof-of-concept experiments to probe internal microbial inactivation rates. This data will then be assessed with regards to conventional X-ray sources and emerging high-efficiency flat panel sources. Before full-scale research efforts are expended, it should also be demonstrated that the expected X-ray and UVC doses required to adequately curtail fouling are not high enough to significantly impact the working lifetimes of membranes. The PIs propose 10 months of experiments to explore these factors and reveal the feasibility of RMBC without requiring intensive prototype development. The approach being proposed is; (1) the first known method of achieving UV inactivation of bacteria within small spaces confined by UV-opaque materials, and, (2) the first use of UV radiation in directly deterring biofouling within modules. While the individual phenomena of X-ray transmission, RL, and UVC microbial inactivation are qualitatively well-understood - though in disparate contexts - this project will be the first to demonstrate how they perform in succession and to quantify the outcome. The research will thus support the PI's goals of instilling greater interaction between students in these two fields in order to encourage advancement of transformative sustainable technologies. The PIs have also developed a plan to include undergraduate summer interns of underrepresented minorities in future embodiments of this research.

por.por_cntn:
The project  titled “EAGER: UVC microbial inactivation within model water treatment membrane modules via X-ray-driven radioluminescence” successfully completed preliminary evaluations of a novel and potentially transformative new method for preventing bacterial colonization in reverse osmosis (RO) membrane water treatment systems. Such colonization, known as biofouling, is highly detrimental to the performance of many RO systems. The method ultimately targets the production of germicidal ultraviolet radiation (UVC) and inactivation of bacteria within the interior spaces of RO modules using radioluminescence (RL) materials activated by an external X-ray source. The specific objectives related to the award were to evaluate the bacterial inactivation rates resulting from UVC produced by X-ray-driven RL, and to determine the dose tolerance of RO membranes to UVC radiation, with respect to damage and performance.  These objectives were designed to test key unknowns and demonstrate basic viability of the concept to justify continued research efforts.

            Outcomes relating to intellectual merit included successful synthesis and testing of UVC-emitting RL materials. Several phosphor candidates were selected and their UV emission properties were characterized using RL spectroscopy. Emission of germicidal wavelengths in the 220-280 nm range was desired, and several materials were developed using Pr3+ doping that met this criteria. These included LaPO4:Pr3+ and YPO4:Pr3+ systems, with the former having properties most desirable for membrane anti-fouling applications. Coatings of the phosphors placed in contact with E. coli suspensions were then evaluated for bactericidal action under X-ray irradiation. Successful inactivation of bacteria was observed upon what is believed to be practical X-ray doses and the results showed that the method has good potential for application to water treatment systems. X-ray dose response relationships were developed, and the contributions of UVC emission to inactivation rates were distinguished from radiolytic effects.

            The vulnerability or RO membranes to UVC photo-damage was also evaluated and quantitative dose tolerance data was a valuable outcome of the project. Membrane coupons were irradiated with UVC from a collimated beam apparatus and salt rejection during RO operation was monitored as indicator of membrane performance. Critical UVC dose was clearly established for representative membranes and our analysis found that this dose exceeded that which is likely needed for biofouling prevention using RL over the membrane lifetime. Hence, the susceptibility of RO membranes to UVC photo-damage was found to not be a limiting factor in advancing this technology.

            Among the broader impacts of the project outcomes was a quantitative determination of the absolute UVC yield of RL phosphors. The values obtained may serve to guide future efforts regarding application of RL systems to biological and anti-biological applications, as our results are among the first to study a microbial response to RL. Furthermore, the team of graduate students, postdocs, and undergraduate research assistants benefited from the collaborative and interdisciplinary experience that this project provided. The results were disseminated in a peer-reviewed publication and several presentations at national environmental engineering and chemistry conferences.
